You must therefore place a certain amount of responsibility upon the people who elect the local representatives, and if you do not mean to be actually discourteous and very unfair to the local representatives, you certainly will not insinuate —and it is very much insinuated—that the local representatives are not responsible people.

MainHeading.P: Undoubtedly there has been a strong desire on the part of public bodies for some time back to have a scheme of this sort put into effect, because very often local representatives were at a disadvantage in finding the best candidates. The absence of any test was certainly a disadvantage, and local representatives very often found it an inconvenience. But they were not prepared to agree to having full power taken out of their hands, and at the same time have the insinuation made against them that they were incompetent, dishonest and open to corruption, and in that way that they were not fit to be public administrators. But it goes further: If we are to argue that the scheme in the past has been unsuccessful and requires alteration, we must naturally conclude that a great number of appointments made by the various county councils have been unsatisfactory. I wonder if the supporters of the Act here and the representatives of the Local Government Department admit that local officials all over the country are generally unsatisfactory?

The appointment of the examining body has already been referred to. Undoubtedly, as I have stated, the whole explanation of the Act is that there has been in the past too much local touch and that public representatives were not enabled to do according to their best intentions. But I have found that in the setting up of this examining body the Local Appointments Commissioners have, on some occasions at least, selected these examining bodies from the local people. What I fail to understand is how it can be claimed that the local representatives, selected by the people to act as county councillors, cannot be trusted to act impartially, and that local people in some instances have actually been appointed from the boards who have later to make the appointment, and I cannot understand how these men can be discovered to be honest and fair-minded by a few men up in Dublin. I think that is inconsistent. What makes the thing very objectionable is that when the examination takes place and the result is sent down by the Local Appointments Commissioners, they give no public announcement of the result of that examination, beyond sending down the name of the selected candidate to the local body. If they are to remove any doubts in the minds of the people—why people—and I assure you there are doubts in the minds of the people—why not submit the result of the examination in respect of all the candidates. and let the local body see how the position stood? But it is a matter of closing the desk upon every applicant's position except the one selected, and that gives a good deal of foundation for the belief that there is not fair play and that the best candidate does not get the position. The Minister for Finance referred to the great results of this system as shown by the fact that the number of applicants for these posts has considerably increased. I can tell him, from opinions gathered in the country, that the opposite will be the result, because a strong opinion prevails, grounded upon a good deal of fact, that on account of the secrecy that is observed by the Appointments Commissioners, the number of applicants will be very much reduced.

I referred here on another occasion to the appointment of an assistant matron in the mental hospital and I pointed out that in the opinion of the Sligo and Leitrim Joint Committee the appointment was not carried out in such a manner as would justify them in agreeing to it. The result was that they turned down the decision. Notification of the examination was sent out five days before the examination. One of the applicants was at home when she made her application, but subsequently had gone to a position in England. The letter notifying her of the examination was sent to her home address, and by the time it reached her she could not give notice and be back in time for her examination.

Speaker.P: Why did she not advise them of her change of address?

I am not in a position to answer that, but it seems strange that only five days' notice of the examination should be given. Some allowance should be made for changes of address like that, particularly as the appointment was under consideration for at least two months before the Commissioners fixed the date of the examination. Cases such as that show conclusively that the Act is not appreciated by the country. I know of public bodies that approved of the principle of the scheme at the outset, but who from their experience of its administration have definitely set their faces against it. I say to Ministers that if they want to restore the confidence that local bodies should have in themselves and the self-respect that is necessary, if they are to become honest administrators, this House should have confidence in them and hand them back the authority to make selections for appointments according to their own honest judgment. The attitude of the present Appointments Commissioners shows entire lack of confidence in these public representatives. If that spirit is encouraged, the result will be that there will be great difficulty in finding honest, self-respecting men to act on local councils, because they are being branded as incompetent persons who are open to corruption. If these are the kind of men that Deputies opposite are putting forward as their candidates in this election, I shall be surprised if the country does not express its opinion of what it thinks of them, because, after all, the country does not like men who distrust themselves.

Speaker.hpid: PARLIAMENTARY SECRETARY to the MINISTER for FINANCE (Mr. Bourke) Seamus Aloysius Bourke
Speaker.NameTxt: PARLIAMENTARY SECRETARY to the MINISTER for FINANCE (Mr. Bourke)
Speaker.P: I am fundamentally in agreement with the Minister for Finance in deploring the fact that Deputy O'Connell has drawn this red herring in the shape of an amendment across this Bill. I agree on principle with the amendment. I do not consider that the Act in its original form was absolute perfection. Every Act after it has been working for a certain period of time, can be amended to advantage, but I consider that this Bill, introduced by Deputy de Valera, strikes right at the heart of the Principal Act. For that reason I think that opportunity should be given to the Dáil to decide on this particular Bill before we deal with the question of Deputy O'Connell's amendment. I must say that this Bill introduced by Deputy de Valera occasioned me very considerable surprise—surprise, not so much at the contents of the measure itself, as at the source from which it comes. In pre-Treaty days, when many Deputies opposite stood with Deputies on these Benches on a common platform, one of the most cherished planks of that platform was the policy of recruiting officers and employees for local authorities, as to the Civil Service, on the principle of open competitive examination.
We stand for it still.

And the appeal that produced perhaps the readiest response from the electorate that might be considered as independent, as having no Party affiliations, was that epitomised in the slogan “On merit alone.” It would not occasion me any great surprise if the Party in office, confronted with all the difficulties and with the tough realities of administration, had found it necessary to compromise on that idea, and had found it necessary to run away from former promises, but for a Party not faced with those pressing difficulties, for a Party whose hands are as free now as they were at the time when these promises were made, and, moreover, for a Party which has never missed any opportunity of twitting us with, as they allege, having departed from the straight and narrow path laid down by the founders of the Sinn Féin movement, this is certainly a strange and unexpected departure—a departure so unexpected, in fact, that I can find no explanation for it, apart, perhaps, from the proximity of the local elections.

I do not wish in this matter to take up a partisan attitude. I was the one primarily responsible for introducing this Act, and I can assure the House that it was not introduced as a political measure. It was not a measure from which any political kudos was to be obtained. It was an unpopular measure at the time and I realised that very well. It was an Act that was very much criticised, but it is a more popular Act to-day, and its popularity will increase as time goes on and as people realise the good that the Act has conferred upon the public in general. I was in the position of being required to deal with this difficult situation and I was prepared to face the political consequences of doing it. Perhaps, to some extent, I may have suffered in consequence.
It being now 10.30 p.m., the debate stood adjourned.

MainHeading.RHead: DEBATE—SALARY OF SECRETARY OF CORK COUNTY COUNCIL
MainHeading.Title: PRIVATE DEPUTIES' BUSINESS. - ADJOURNMENT DEBATE—SALARY OF SECRETARY OF CORK COUNTY COUNCIL.

Speaker.P: My reason for raising this matter on the Adjournment to-night is that on several occasions I tried to get a satisfactory reply to questions I put on this matter, but could not do so. In the first place, I asked a question last week under four heads. The reply I got covered only one head, and not four. The reply states: “A resolution was passed as stated. It is understood that the inclusive salary referred to operates as from 1st April, 1927.” Then it states further that “an agreement is in course of preparation which has, I understand, presented some drastic difficulties. The County Council have been asked to complete the matter without avoidable delay.” That agreement contains about ten clauses. Clause 6 of that agreement contained a pension clause. When the agreement was sent up in December, 1926, to the Department they sent down a reply to the County Council objecting to the pension clause of the agreement. If that agreement had been operative without the sanction of the Local Government Department—and the Minister's reply does not say it was sanctioned—if it was in operation without sanction then what is the position as regards the pension clause of that agreement which has been objected to by the Department? As a member of the Special Finance Committee, I definitely objected to the pension clause and I sent that objection up to the Department. I considered it very unfair. That clause stated that the Secretary should be paid a pension of £1,033 per annum. and that if necessary for that purpose a number of years were to be added to his years of service so as to entitle him to such a pension.

MainHeading.P: One of the first actions of that Special Finance Committee was to adopt a resolution that no years should be added to any official's years of service in order to entitle him to an increase of pension more than he would be justly entitled to. In the second place, I considered it grossly unfair that in the position that this gentleman holds from the ratepayers and which carries a salary of £480 a year, they should be mulcted on his retirement by providing him with a pension of £1,033. These are the reasons why I raised this matter on the Adjournment. I want to know definitely if that agreement is being brought before the Minister for his sanction, and if so, whether it has been sanctioned or not? If it has not been sanctioned, is it a fact that there is in operation in Cork county a salary under an agreement, a clause of which has been objected to by the Minister? I want this question definitely answered now.

Speaker.hpid: MINISTER FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND PUBLIC HEALTH (General Mulcahy) Richard (General) Mulcahy
Speaker.NameTxt: MINISTER FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND PUBLIC HEALTH (General Mulcahy)
Speaker.P: On the 13th December, 1926, the Cork County Council notified that they proposed to fix an inclusive salary of £1,550 for the Secretary of the Council. This salary was in substitution for remuneration composed of a fixed salary as Secretary of the County Council of £450 per annum, plus certain fees of magnitude, but of varying amount, which probably, in gross amount, exceed £2,000 per annum, from which expenses for clerical assistance are deductible. The proposal of the Cork County Council appeared appropriate, and the action of the Secretary of the County Council in accepting the proposal was generally satisfactory. My letter of the 31st December, 1926, acquiesced in the Council's proposal. I understand that effect has been given to the proposal as from the 1st April, 1927. It was by reason of the fact that the system whereby fees of uncertain amount might accrue to local officials that control was taken of such appointments in the Local Government Act of 1923.

In every case where vacancies have since been filled inclusive salaries have been fixed, e.g., Donegal, Leitrim, Leix and Offaly County Councils. I understand an agreement is in preparation dealing with matters additional to that of Mr. Callanan's salary, and with which I am not concerned. I understand that some delay in perfection of the agreement has arisen. The agreement deals with future superannuation and other matters. I have recommended the Cork County Council to complete the formal agreement.

When the agreement was sent up first, was not objection raised by the Ministry to clause 6 which was an essential portion of the agreement—at least it was held to be so by the secretary? Has that essential clause been passed or not?

I have not seen the agreement, and I will not be in a position either to consider the matter or to make any statement about it until I have seen the agreement and know what the clauses in the agreement are.
So the agreement has not been sanctioned.
The Dáil adjourned at 10.40 p.m.

MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - AFFORESTATION IN CO. WATERFORD.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands and Agriculture whether he can state the reason for the delay in utilising for afforestation the lands of Mickencor and Derrinlaur. County Waterford, which were leased for this purpose about three years ago.

A deed covering the leasing of an area of 711 acres of land lying in the townlands of Derrinlaur Upper, Derrinlaur Lower, Tickincor Upper and Carricknabrone, County Waterford, was executed in 1922 by the Department of Agriculture.

Under the terms of the deed the lands are divided into three blocks, viz:—Block I, containing 314 acres, to be leased as from 1st July, 1922; Block II, containing 289½ acres to be leased as from its complete clearance of mature timber by the lessor not later than 1942; Block III, containing 107½ acres, to be leased as from its complete clearance of mature timber by the lessor not later than 1947.
Block I has been planted by the Department, and as the other two blocks are not yet in hands, they are not available to the Department for immediate planting.

MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - MAYO TENANTS' TURBARY RIGHTS.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. C. HENRY Mr. C. HENRY
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries whether he is aware that the tenants in the townland of Puntabeg, Charlestown, County Mayo, on the Dillon Estate (C.D.B.) were allotted turbary in the townland of Glenmullynahoe, West Bog; and, as they have failed to procure a map of the allotments, whether the Minister will see that their allotments are pointed out to them, and give them an opportunity of providing the necessary fuel for the present season.
Arrangements are being made to have the plots pointed out to the tenants.
